sections.Equipment:
===Gadgets===
{{main|List of James Bond gadgets}}
====Used by Bond====
{| class="article-table article-table-selected" style="width: 100%; " border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1"
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Gadget -_GE Piton.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Grappling Pistol|Piton Gun]]''' — hybrid grapple and laser gun used in the intro sequence when Bond bungee jumps off of a dam. To ensure he doesn't bounce back up he uses this gun to latch on to the complex below using its grapple function. Once down, Bond uses the laser built inside the gun to infiltrate the venting system that leads into the bathroom.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Gadget -_GE DoorDecoder.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Door Decoder]]''' — appears in the pre-titles sequence, used by both Bond and Trevelyan to get into the Facility's bottling room.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_GE_-_Camera.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Digital Binoculars]]''' - Auto focus/zoom, digital camera, satellite uplink to send visual data.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Gadget -_GE Belt.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Rappelling Belt]]''' — Q gives Bond a size-34 belt containing a 75-foot rappelling cord and a piton-shooting buckle. When fired, it shoots a grapple attached to high-tensile-strength wire designed to support Bond's weight.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Laser watch, inactive (GoldenEye, 1995).png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Omega Seamaster]] / [[Laser Wristwatch]]''' — This watch, standard issue of MI6, has a built-in laser that can cut through steel and iron, and can also remotely detonate mines.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Pen grenade (GoldenEye).png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Explosive Pen]]''' — Q-Branch gives Bond a pen that doubles as a "class four" (fictional designation) grenade. Three clicks arms the four-second fuse, another three disarms it.
|-
|}
====Q-Lab background====
{| class="article-table article-table-selected" style="width: 100%; " border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1"
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_GE_-_Cast.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Wheelchair Missile Launcher]]''' - Tested by Q Branch, this gadget was made to look like someone had broken their leg, when in fact, the leg hid a missile, which could be fired from the seated position.
|-
|style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_GE_-_Phonebooth.png|100px]]
|style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[Phone Booth Trap]]''' - Q Branch is testing a BT telephone box with a large airbag inside which expands, crushing anyone inside against the wall of the box.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;"|[[File:Gadgets_-_GE_-_X-Ray_Tray.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;"|'''[[X-Ray Document Scanner]]''' - Q has a document scanner disguised as a tea-tray.
|-
|}

===Weapons===
{{main articles|[[List of Firearms]] and [[:Category:GoldenEye (film) Weapons|GoldenEye (film) Weapons]]}}
====Used on-screen====
{| class="article-table article-table-selected" style="width: 100%; " border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1"
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Walther-PPK.jpg|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Walther PPK]]''' - James Bond's standard-issue pistol. Shown in the poster below with suppressor. Chambered for the 7.65mm x 17 Browning (or .32 ACP) cartridge.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:MakarovPM Bondwiki1.jpg|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Makarov PM]]''' — The pistol was prominently used by[[General Ourumov (Gottfried John)| General Arkady Grigorovich Ourumov]] in a number of scenes in the movie. [[Natalya Simonova (Izabella Scorupco)|Natalya Simonova]] was seen using a [[Makarov PM]] when she commandeered one of the Janus helicopter gunships to rescue Bond from the satellite dish's antenna before it exploded.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Bondwiki1 BDM Pistol1.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Browning BDM]]''' — [[Alec Trevelyan (Sean Bean)|Alec Trevelyan]]'s pistol of choice. At the beginning during the facility infiltration, he is seen with a Browning BDA (FN HP-DA) and the ending battle scene at the antenna cradle is seen with a Browning BDM. <small>(Due to continuity error, the BDA only appears in the pantry at Arkhangelsk, and Alec uses the BDM for the rest of the film. Both guns are a evolution of the ubiquitous [[Browning Hi-Power]] pistol, with BDA released in 1983 and BDM in 1991.</small>
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Unknown - Infobox.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Astra 2000 Cub''' — used by Xenia Onatopp to assassinate the two Tiger Pilots.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Unknown - Infobox.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''CZ 52''' — semi-automatic pistol wielded by [[Valentin Zukovsky (Robbie Coltrane)|Zukovsky]] to intimidate Bond.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:BondWiki AK74 Early1.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Kalashnikov [[AK-74]] rifle''' — Standard-issue assault rifle of the Soviet/Russian armed forces and has been in Soviet/Russian military service since 1974/1975. Chambered for the 5.45mm x 39 Soviet M74 cartridge.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:AKS74U Bondwiki 1.jpg|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Kalashnikov [[Kalashnikov Rifle|AKS-74U]] carbine''' — The AKS-74u was prominently used by James Bond at the Arkangel Chemical Weapons Facility in 1986 and in St. Petersburg in 1995 when he and Natalya were escaping from the Russian military base. The AKSU-74 was also used by [[Xenia Onatopp (Famke Janssen)|Xenia Onatopp]] when she used the weapon to kill the personnel at the Severnaya satellite control centre after General Ourumov got control of the two GoldenEye satellites. Bond can be seen wielding it on Trevelyan's Train. Also chambered for the 5.45mm x 39 Soviet M74 cartridge.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Unknown - Infobox.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Timed Explosive]]''' — used by Bond at Arkhangelsk Chemical Facility to destroy the gas tanks and facility.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Gadgets - GE - Mine.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Remote-detonated [[Limpet Mine]]''' — explosives with magnetic properties which are detonated with the use of Omega Seamaster watch's detonator. Used by Bond at the Cuban Satellite Control Centre to try sabotage the computer epicenter.
|-
|}

====Deleted scene====
{| class="article-table article-table-selected" style="width: 100%; " border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1"
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Bondwiki Glock17 G2.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Glock 17]] (Chinese counterfeit)''' — One of the weapons the Pakistani weapons dealer tries to sell to Zukovsky, latter who professes his love for the gun only to turn it against the former. Zuvosky then telling that the Chinese made a batch of counterfeits and scares the dealer by attempting to shoot him, only for the gun not to fire, since the Chinese made the firing pin is too short.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Mp5a2.jpg|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[H&K MP5]] (Czech counterfeit)''' — One of the weapons the Pakistani weapons dealer tries to sell to Zukovsky, latter who deems the MP5 to be obsolete hardware and "Czech counterfeit crap" to boot.
|-
|}

====Background/low presence weapons====
* FN/Browning HP-DA (Alec's gun in the Chemical Facility pantry)
* MAS / MAC mle. 1950 pistol (French navy security, after Tiger is stolen)
* [[SVD Dragunov]] (Soviet soldiers, pre-titles)
* RPK (Soviet soldiers, pre-titles)
* RPD Light Machine Gun (Soviet soldiers, pre-titles)
* PKM Machine Gun (Soviet soldiers, pre-titles)
* MAS-49/56 Rifle (French sailors at frigate)
* Remington Rolling Block (on display at Zukovsky's office)
* [[M16A2]] (US Marines at the end)
* DShK (atop T-55)
* [[RPG-7]] (Soviet soldiers, pre-titles)
* M134 Minigun (Q-lab)
* Mk 19 Grenade Launcher (Q-lab)
* [[M136 AT4]] (Q-lab)

====Fake AK-rifles====
[[File:NorincoType56wAK74muzzle.png|right|220px|thumb|Chinese Type 56-1 rifle with AK-74 muzzle brake. The movie version also features a AK-74-style red Bakelite magazines not depicted in this image.]]
In the movie ''GoldenEye'', a number of the AK-74 rifles that were used during filming were not real AK-74s but non-Russian made Kalashnikov rifles that were made to look like the AK-74 rifle. The folding-stock variant AK-74 rifles that were seen in ''GoldenEye'' were Chinese-made Norinco Type 56/AKM rifles that were fitted with AK-74-style muzzle brakes and Russian-make red Bakelite plastic magazines that were made for the AKM rifle in the 1970s. The rifles that were fitted with fixed butt-stocks were real, Russian-made AK-74 rifles.

sections.Used by Bond:
{| class="article-table article-table-selected" style="width: 100%; " border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1"
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle_-_Aston_Martin_DB5.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Aston Martin DB5]]''' - Registration BMT214A. Note this is not the same car as seen in ''[[Goldfinger]]'' and ''[[Thunderball]]'' (that car was registered BMT216A). This appears to be Bond's personal car and re-appears in the next film ''[[Tomorrow Never Dies (film)|Tomorrow Never Dies]]'' (its appearance at Castle Thane in ''[[The World Is Not Enough]]'' did not make it into the final film). The car is equipped with a refrigerator in the centre armrest to hold champagne and two glasses, and also a communications system including fax and voice commands.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle_-_BMW_Z3.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[BMW Z3]]''' - A convertible, it comes fully loaded with all the usual Q refinements including a self-destruct system and stinger missiles located behind the headlights. In the movie, Bond uses none of the car's gadgets (except for the covert receipt-like printer disguised as a mobile CD player). He ends up trading it for Jack Wade's plane in the Caribbean region.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle_-_T54_Tank.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[T-55]] battle tank''' - A Russian tank taken by Bond to pursue [[General Ourumov (Gottfried John)|General Ourumov]] in [[wikipedia:Saint Petersburg|St. Petersburg]].
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle_-_Cagiva 350 T4.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Cagiva W16 600]]''' - Motorcycle used by [[Arkangel Chemical Weapons Facility]] troops. Bond ends up taking one to catch the unpiloted plane.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle_-_Pilatus PC-6 Porter.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Pilatus PC-6]]/B2-H2 Turbo Porter''' - Used by Bond to escape the [[Arkangel Chemical Weapons Facility]].
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:BondWiki1 GE RivaMonteCarlo30 Brosnan.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Riva Monte Carlo 30 Offshorer''' – Used by Bond to get aboard Manticore and then leave it to try catch Xenia at the La Fayette frigate.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Vehicle_-_Cessna_172.png]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Cessna 172|Cessna 172P Skyhawk]]''' - Used by Bond and Natalya in Cuba to scout for the [[Janus Satellite Control Centre]]. Shot down by an underwater Surface-to-Air Missile.
|-
|}

Bond can be seen wielding it on Trevelyan's Train. Also chambered for the 5.45mm x 39 Soviet M74 cartridge.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Unknown - Infobox.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''[[Timed Explosive]]''' — used by Bond at Arkhangelsk Chemical Facility to destroy the gas tanks and facility.
|-
| style="vertical-align:top;background-color:transparent;" |[[File:Gadgets - GE - Mine.png|100px]]
| style="background-color:transparent;" |'''Remote-detonated [[Limpet Mine]]''' — explosives with magnetic properties which are detonated with the use of Omega Seamaster watch's detonator. Used by Bond at the Cuban Satellite Control Centre to try sabotage the computer epicenter.
|-

sections.Fake AK-rifles:
[[File:NorincoType56wAK74muzzle.png|right|220px|thumb|Chinese Type 56-1 rifle with AK-74 muzzle brake. The movie version also features a AK-74-style red Bakelite magazines not depicted in this image.]]
In the movie ''GoldenEye'', a number of the AK-74 rifles that were used during filming were not real AK-74s but non-Russian made Kalashnikov rifles that were made to look like the AK-74 rifle. The folding-stock variant AK-74 rifles that were seen in ''GoldenEye'' were Chinese-made Norinco Type 56/AKM rifles that were fitted with AK-74-style muzzle brakes and Russian-make red Bakelite plastic magazines that were made for the AKM rifle in the 1970s. The rifles that were fitted with fixed butt-stocks were real, Russian-made AK-74 rifles.

sections.Video games:
:''Main article: [[GoldenEye 007 (1997 game)|GoldenEye 007 (N64)]], [[GoldenEye: Rogue Agent]] and [[GoldenEye 007 (2010 game)|GoldenEye 007/GoldenEye Reloaded (Wii/PS3/Xbox 360)]]''
[[File:Frigate Goldeneye 007.png|thumb|240x240px|''GoldenEye 007'', the film's video game adaption on the Nintendo 64]]
''GoldenEye'' was adapted into a [[GoldenEye 007 (1997 game)|highly successful video game]] for the Nintendo 64 by [[Nintendo]] and [[Rare]] in 1997. At the time of its release, it was considered a flagship game for the console, and was revolutionary in First-Person Shooter history which led to many later games and series inspired by it, including the ''Bond'' series itself; It ultimately sold over 8 million units - making it the 3rd best-selling title for the N64 (behind only Nintendo's own ''Super Mario 64'' and ''Mario Kart 64'') and it is still widely regarded as the best [[James Bond Video Games|''James Bond'' video game]] as well as one of the greatest of all time. Interestingly, ''GoldenEye 007'' was originally planned to be an on-rails shooter game intended for the N64's predecessor, the Super NES. The game itself was popular enough to gain another critically acclaimed game, a spiritual successor called ''[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perfect_Dark Perfect Dark]'', also by Rare on the Nintendo 64, three years after its release.

In the Autumn of 2004, [[Electronic Arts]] released ''[[GoldenEye: Rogue Agent]]'' for the Xbox, Sony PlayStation 2, Nintendo GameCube and later the Nintendo DS. This is the first game based on the ''James Bond'' franchise in which the player does not take on the role of James Bond himself; rather they control a 00-Agent candidate (ironically named [[GoldenEye (character)|GoldenEye]]) who is recruited by [[Auric Goldfinger]], the [[List of James Bond villains|Bond Villain]] in the novel/film ''[[Goldfinger]]''. Despite its name, the title has little to do with either the film ''GoldenEye'' or its video game adaptation, and was released to mediocre reviews, and was criticized for using the "GoldenEye" name in an attempt to sell the game by riding on the success of Rare's game.

In 2010, Activision and Eurocom produced a [[GoldenEye 007 (2010 game)|re-imagining of the ''GoldenEye 007'' game]], albeit with major changes to the plot and graphics (Rareware had been acquired by Microsoft in 2002). Some changes include the likeness of [[Daniel Craig]] as James Bond instead of [[Pierce Brosnan]], the removal of Boris, and different level layouts. Originally a Nintendo Wii/DS exclusive, it was later released on the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 as ''GoldenEye: Reloaded''. It was moderately well-received, though not to the extent of the original N64 game.
sections.Trivia:
===Similarity with other Bond stories===
====Moonraker novel====
Its been observed GoldenEye has similarities with the original 1955 [[Moonraker (novel)|Moonraker novel]]; while they aren't 1:1 directly connected, they have some similar elements in their story structure. 
* The villains - [[Sir Hugo Drax (Literary)|Sir Hugo Drax]] and Alec Trevelyan - are both supposed British allies who end up revealed to be traitors. What's more, both of their motives are derived from things that happened during [[World War II]], with Drax motivated by Nazi Germany's loss and Trevelyan by the British repatriation of Lienz Cossacks. Also, both have halves of their faces burned, which resulted from a military operation that resulted in change of side. It should also be noted that both these villains are considered the best developed Bond villains of their perspective decades.
* Both of villain's plans involve using a nuclear weapon to devastate London and profit from it; with Sir Drax using the Moonraker tactical missile and stockmarket trickery to reap profits from destruction, while Trevelyan is using the stolen GoldenEye EMP weapon to cover the computer hacker theft into Bank of England.
* The Bond girl is integral in undoing the nuclear weapon in both stories; Gala Brand redirects the Moonraker missile to explode at sea, while Natalya Simonova sets of the GoldenEye's EMP's retro-rockets to make it self-destruct at earth's atmosphere.
* Both have elaborate car chases in a major city with the Bond girl held as villain's hostage in the car that's chased; Moonraker novel has the Bond's Bentley vs. Drax's Mercedes-Benz, and GoldenEye has Bond's T-55 vs. Ourumov's GAZ Volga.

====Never Say Never Again (+ Thunderball)====
There are quite a few story-line similarities with the plot of the unofficial 1983 Bond film ''[[Never Say Never Again]]''.
* M is depicted being disdainful of Bond's archaic nature. GoldenEye's M deems Bond a "sexist misogynistic dinosaur" and a relic of the cold war, while NSNA's M deems that Bond is a under-performer not up the standards of his MI6 reign.
* Villains are more complicated than typical Bond villain. GoldenEye's Alec Trevelyan has (somewhat) sympathetic motives and complicated relationship with Bond; while NSNA's Maximillian Largo exhibits rather realistic psychopathic and emotionally manipulative tendencies.
* France/Monaco is featured as a notable setting; with Monte Carlo Casino being one of the places Bond visits, although in NSNA its not expressly meant to be the Monte Carlo Casino.
* Both feature degree of computer technology.
* Xenia Ontatopp's unhinged behavior mirrors that of [[Fatima Blush]].
* Both have scenes in which Bond uses a [[Laser Wristwatch|laser wristwatch]] to escape containment.
* Both feature a pencil gadget; the pencil projectile launcher in NSNA and the exploding pen in GoldenEye.
* Both films have Bond return to a car not seen in a while. (The Bentley in NSNA, the DB5 in GoldenEye)
* Both films are composed by French composers; Michel LeGrand for NSNA and Eric Serra for GoldenEye.
* Both begin with a military operation in which Bond is betrayed. Except in NSNA the betrayal is near-immediate, while in GoldenEye it takes a while before Bond realized that Trevelyan betrayed him in the opening mission.
* Both have Bond's health being evaluated near the beginning of the film. Bond is sent to Shrublands in NSNA, while Caroline performs a psychiatric evaluation in Monaco to Bond.
* Both feature villain using high-ranking officer credentials gaining access to a well-guarded vault for controls of a nuclear weapon; General Ourumov in GoldenEye and Jack Petachi in NSNA.
* While more connected to the original 1965 ''[[Thunderball]]'', Xenia's theft of Tiger mirrors the theft of the V-Force [[Avro Vulcan]] bomber.
* Both feature Bond in green jungle fatigues. NSNA's Bond has them at the beginning, while GoldenEye's Bond has them by the finale.
* Both have Bond driving a motorcycle, which never happened in other Bond movies prior to GoldenEye.

===Other trivia===
*While this is the first appearance of [[Pierce Brosnan]] as [[James Bond (Pierce Brosnan)|James Bond]], he was actually picked to replace [[Roger Moore]] in the 1987 film ''[[The Living Daylights]]'', but due to his contract with the television show, ''[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remington_Steele Remington Steele]'' (which is known for launching his career prior to becoming 007), he had to drop out of the film and the role was ultimately given to [[Timothy Dalton]], instead. 
**Indeed, the pre-titles Arkhangelsk sequence takes place in 1986, when Brosnan was originally meant to begin his Bond tenure.
*''GoldenEye'' was the first ''James Bond'' film to have filmed on location inside the former Soviet Union (Russia), a country which had banned all sixteen previous movies.
*Earlier on the year of ''GoldenEye''<nowiki/>'s release, [[Alan Cumming]] (who portrayed [[Janus Syndicate|Janus]]' computer whiz [[Boris Grishenko]]) and [[Minnie Driver]] (who portrayed [[Valentin Zukovsky (Robbie Coltrane)|Zukovsky]]'s mistress [[Irina (Minnie Driver)|Irina]]) had shared several scenes together in the film adaptation of Maeve Binchy's romantic/friendship novel ''[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circle_of_Friends_(1995_film) Circle of Friends].'' In ''GoldenEye'', however, they never appeared together onscreen. Driver also had no spoken lines in ''GoldenEye'' except singing the lyrics of "Stand by Your Man" by Tammy Wynette.[[File:GoldenEye (Amazon digital 2023).jpg|thumb|187x187px|The 2023 Amazon Digital promotion image of the movie shows a genuine "GoldenEye"]]
*Ironically, a promotional pictur<nowiki/>e for the film exists of an iris with a golden color, hence the name "GoldenEye".
*For a time it was rumoured that Brosnan's contract specifically stated that he was not allowed to wear a full tuxedo in other films and that Brosnan had apparently worked around this in the film ''[[Wikipedia:The Thomas Crown Affair (1999 film)|The Thomas Crown Affair]]'' by leaving his tie untied during a black-tie ball, thus not wearing a full tuxedo. This rumor turned out to be false.
*Minnie Driver (Irina) and [[Izabella Scorupco]] ([[Natalya Simonova (Izabella Scorupco)|Natalya Simonova]]) had appeared alongside American actor [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_O%27Donnell Chris O'Donnell] in different movies. Driver in ''Circle of Friends'' and Scorupco in ''[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertical_Limit Vertical Limit]''. Alan Cumming (Boris Grishenko) also appeared in ''Circle of Friends'', but never had scenes together with O'Donnell in the movie. Pierce Brosnan attended the premiere of ''Vertical Limit'' and posed with O'Donnell and the latter's ''Vertical Limit'' co-star [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Paxton Bill Paxton] for a photograph during the event.
*''GoldenEye'' features the highest bungee jump from a structure in a movie, performed by British stuntman Wayne Michaels. The drop was more than 722ft. At the time, it was the highest bungee jump of any kind.
* Joe Don Baker returned as CIA agent Jack Wade in the sequel ''[[Tomorrow Never Dies]]'': his previous appearance in the Bond films was as the villain [[Brad Whitaker]] in ''[[The Living Daylights]]''. Baker had played a similar character, also a CIA agent, for ''GoldenEye'' director [[Martin Campbell]] in the 1985 BBC television drama ''Edge of Darkness''. Baker became the second actor to portray both Bond's main adversary and Bond's ally (after [[Charles Gray]] who portrayed [[Dikko Henderson (Charles Gray)|a murdered MI6 contact]] in Tokyo in ''[[You Only Live Twice (film)|You Only Live Twice]]'' and would later play [[Blofeld (classic film continuity)|Blofeld]] in ''[[Diamonds Are Forever (film)|Diamonds Are Forever]]''), and the first one to play the ally character twice after previously played a different main villain character.
*Maurice Binder, the title sequence designer for most of the ''James Bond'' films since ''[[Dr. No]]'', died in 1991. The job of title designer for ''GoldenEye'' as well as several future ''James Bond'' films was then passed to Daniel Kleinman.
*Albert "Cubby" Broccoli died shortly after the film was released. He had been too ill but could visit the Pinewood studios by being a consulting Producer. The next ''Bond'' film, ''[[Tomorrow Never Dies]]'', was dedicated to his memory.
*This is the first ''James Bond'' film where the MI6 Headquarters scenes are being filmed and set in its [[SIS Building|actual real-life building]].
*This is also the first film where MI6 is referred as such. Previously it was called British Secret Service, as officially MI6 did not exist before going public in 1994.
*The uniform of the Canadian Admiral was incorrect. The admiral was shown with two bars and an executive curl on the cuffs of his tunic. As this was filmed in 1995, the admiral's uniform should have one solid bar on the cuffs, and three maple leaves on the shoulders, and without the wings on the sleeve. The Canadian Navy would have these restored in 2010.
*Boris the programmer's global tracking software features the outline of a united Czechoslovakia on its map, even though the country had (peacefully) split into the Czech Republic and the Slovak Republic in 1993, two years before that part of the film takes place.
*Xenia Onatopp is shown to kill men by squeezing their chests with her thighs. In the previous Bond film [[The Living Daylights]], [[Q (Desmond Llewelyn)|Q]] reviews a range of Soviet KGB female assassins, one of which, [[Ula Yarkhov]], kills using her thighs.
*''GoldenEye'' has the distinction of being the first - and currently, the only - EON-produced ''James Bond'' film to include a semi-explicit sex scene, specifically the scene in which Xenia kills the Canadian Naval Admiral while making love to him. Despite this, the film was still released with a PG-13 rating.
*In a scene set at Q lab, Bond and Q test an exploding pen which successfully works, prompting Bond to quip, "''The writing's on the wall?''". The phrase would later become the title of the main theme to ''[[Spectre (film)|Spectre]]'', starring [[James Bond (Daniel Craig)|Daniel Craig as Bond]].
*This was the only Brosnan ''Bond'' film not to be released in the same year as a ''Austin Powers'' movie, the movie series that parodied ''James Bond''.
*The first ''James Bond'' film to be released in the 1990s and the first to be released in the two year chronological odd-numbered gap.
